bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, August 18, 1925 [Enclosed in C0309001]

div1.p: Noguchi comments on the importance of determining mosquito infectivity and possible animal immunity in experiments on mosquito transmission of yellow fever in animals.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, August 18, 1925 [Enclosed in C0309001]
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter containing a section of Dr. Beeuwkes's
diary. It is quite interesting to note that the clinical pictures of these
cases are not as clear cut as we would like to have. Among those cases seen
by Dr. Beeuwkes there is a particle of uncertainty in diagnosis. I am interested
to know if the guinea pigs used by Dr. Connal were young and freshly imported
from non-yellow fever countries. It does make a world of difference whether
suitable animals are being used in transmission experiments. It would be mis-
leading to emphasize the negative results without definitely stating the animal
material employed for such an experiment. Certainly nothing can be decided by
this sort of procedures.

Regarding the mosquito transmission experiments, I am quite aware of
difficulty in obtaining a positive result unless many attempts are being re-
peated with fresh animals. When one animal remains without any reaction,
that particular animal is undoubtedly immune, so others must be tried. The
fundamental question in Mrs. Connal's experiment is whether or not that or those
mosquitoes are really infective even for human non-immunes. When you obtain
a positive transmission to a guinea pig there is no question that the mosquitoes
used were infective, but when you get a negative outcome, the infectivity of the
insects needs verification by some other mode of experimentation. Guinea pigs
are by no means very reliable for such determination. I would like to see some
volunteers tested out as had been done in Havana. For that matter, chimpanzees
may be used for such purposes, particularly because these apes are more readily
accessible to our need there. If I am to be there myself I would certainly

carry out this program for determining the nature of the disease known
as yellow fever by some and denied by others. Of course, if Muller suc-
ceeds in isolating Leptospira Icteroides this settles the identity of the disease
with yellow fever in the new world. Or even the Pfeiffer reaction will
bring the question nearer its solution. ..........

Please keep me informed of any development in the African
expedition.

closer.salute:
With kindest regards, I am
Very sincerely yours,
